elements.title: Risks Involved in Acquisitions

data.value: Difficulties in integrating operations, systems, technologies, products, and personnel of the acquired businesses.
Difficulties in entering markets with limited prior experience and competitors with stronger positions.
Diversion of management’s attention from normal daily operations.
Potential loss of key employees, customers, and business partners of acquired businesses.
Use a substantial portion of cash resources or incur debt, leading to increased interest expense and leverage.
Assume liabilities associated with acquisitions.
Issue common stock that would dilute current stockholders’ ownership.
Record goodwill and intangible assets subject to impairment testing.
Become subject to intellectual property or other litigation.
Effective tax rate may be impacted by mergers and acquisitions.

elements.title: ZIFF DAVIS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - CONTINUED

data.value: Asset classified as held for sale if: (i) approved and committed to a sale plan; (ii) available for immediate sale in current condition; (iii) active buyer search and related actions initiated; (iv) sale is probable and expected within one year; (v) actively marketed at a price reasonable relative to fair value; (vi) unlikely for significant changes to the plan.

data.key: Measurement of Held for Sale Assets
data.value: Measured at the lower of carrying value or fair value less costs to sell. Losses recognized when classification criteria met; gains recognized only upon sale. Depreciation ceases upon designation.

data.key: Business Combinations and Valuation of Goodwill
data.value: Acquisition method per GAAP used. Purchase prices are allocated to the fair value of acquired assets including identifiable intangible assets; uses estimates (revenue growth, margins, discount rates, etc.). Fair value estimates may be refined for up to one year after acquisition.

Goodwill is the excess of purchase price over net tangible and identifiable intangible assets. Identifiable intangibles (e.g., customer relationships, trademarks, trade names, developed technologies) are recorded at fair value and amortized over 1-20 years if finite. Indefinite-lived intangibles are tested annually for impairment.

Annual impairment tests are performed for goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets using both qualitative and quantitative assessments. Recorded goodwill impairments: $27.4M in 2022, $32.6M in 2021, and none in 2020.

Some acquisition agreements include contingent earn-out arrangements based on future income thresholds or other metrics. Fair value of these arrangements is included in the purchase price and recorded as a liability.

elements.title: ZIFF DAVIS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - CONTINUED

data.value: The contingent earn-out formula is a critical and material component of the valuation approach for determining the purchase price, indicating that the initial consideration is not the sole basis for acquisition valuation.
Measured at fair value on a recurring basis using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3), with valuation techniques such as a Monte-Carlo simulation to model potential outcomes.
Amounts paid less than or equal to the liability on the acquisition date are reflected as cash used in financing activities, whereas any excess is recorded as cash used in operating activities.
Former shareholders of acquired companies who remain as key employees receive compensation at levels comparable to the company’s other key employees, separate from the contingent earn-out payments.
The estimated fair value of the contingent earn-out liabilities is reviewed and re-assessed quarterly, with changes recognized in general and administrative expenses.
The company provides health and dental insurance through a self-insurance structure with secured reinsurance in the form of two-tiered stop-loss coverage.
Income tax positions are evaluated under ASC Topic 740, with reserves established for tax uncertainties based on uncertainties in tax positions and potential challenges.

elements.title: Overview of Digital Health and Media Portfolio

data.value: Everyday Health – a medically reviewed, award-winning digital content platform for health and wellness.

Includes interactive guides, resource centers, special reports, community health tip sharing, newsletters, self-assessment tools, healthcare finders, e-courses, and lifestyle programs. Other owned sites include DailyOM, Diabetes Daily, and Migraine Again.
Everyday Health Trusted Care Access Portfolio (TCAP) featuring digital properties of renowned medical centers with exclusive advertising representation.
Lose It! – a comprehensive, app-based weight loss program; Emma’s Diary – a resource offering advice and guidance for expectant mothers in the UK.
MedPage Today delivers daily breaking medical news and policy updates; PRIME Education provides accredited CME/CE programs; Health eCareers connects healthcare professionals with job opportunities.
Faces intense competition from diversified digital media companies (e.g., IAC/InterActiveCorp, Future PLC), vertical-specific companies, and major ad sellers such as Alphabet, Meta, and Snap.
Provides subscription-based SaaS solutions with relatively stable and predictable revenue.

elements.title: Revenue Recognition Policies and Long-lived Asset Impairment

data.value: Revenue will be recognized when performance obligations are met, either over time or at a specific point in time depending on the nature of the obligation.
Recognized upfront at the point in time when the software is made available to the customer for download and use.
Recognized ratably over the contractual period as support services are provided, including technical support and software upgrades or patches as they become available.

Hardware products and related software (e.g., operating system or firmware) are treated as a bundled performance obligation, with revenue recognized at the point in time of delivery and transfer of ownership.
Generally recognized over time as the services are performed.

Consist of subscription fees and usage-based fees, with portions collected in advance deferred and recognized as the related performance obligations are satisfied. Reseller revenues are recorded on a gross basis where control precedes transfer.

Long-lived assets, including property, equipment, and identifiable intangible assets, are reviewed for impairment based on indicators such as underperformance, changes in asset use or strategy, industry trends, sustained stock price declines, and market capitalization compared to net book value. An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying amount exceeds the estimated fair value.

elements.title: Impairment Testing and Valuation of Goodwill and Intangible Assets

data.value: The Company evaluated whether events or changes in circumstances may indicate that the carrying amounts of definite-lived intangibles and long-lived assets might not be recoverable. No impairment of long-lived assets was recorded for the years 2022 and 2021 except for certain operating right-of-use assets, and none for 2020.

Long-lived assets are classified as held for sale when they meet specific criteria such as having an approved sale plan, immediate availability, active marketing at a reasonable price relative to fair value, and a probable sale within one year. Depreciation ceases upon designation.

The Company applies the acquisition method under GAAP for business combinations. Valuations of acquired intangible assets and goodwill are based on estimates from income and market approaches, using significant unobservable inputs and assumptions.
Goodwill impairments of $27.4 million in 2022 and $32.6 million in 2021 were recorded, while no impairment was recognized in 2020.
Fair value assessments of long-lived assets held for sale are made every reporting period, and subsequent adjustments may be recorded to earnings after the measurement period.

Expectation of improved performance through integration of recent acquisitions, shift in advertising transactions from offline to online, and emphasis on monetization via own websites resulting in higher operating margins compared to third-party sites.

elements.title: Operating Costs, Income Metrics and Revenues Analysis

data.value: The table titled 'Operating Costs and Income Statement Metrics (Percentage Analysis)' compares key operating expense items and income indicators for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021. Notable observations include: Total operating expenses decreased from 88% in 2021 to 86% in 2022; Income from operations increased from 12% to 14%; and net income from continuing operations dropped significantly from 29% in 2021 to 5% in 2022.
A separate section shows revenues (in thousands) of $1,390,997 in 2022 versus $1,416,722 in 2021, reflecting a 2% decline.

Revenues are generated from the Digital Media business (primarily advertising, subscriptions, business lead generation, and licensing of editorial content and trademarks) and the Cybersecurity and Martech business (with fixed customer subscriptions and variable usage-based revenues).

The decline in 2022 revenues is attributed mainly to the absence of approximately $33.5 million of revenue from the divested B2B Backup business and Voice assets, partially offset by acquisitions contributing $50.4 million (in 2021) and $33.1 million (in 2022) along with organic growth in various segments.

elements.title: Share Buyback and Stockholders’ Equity Notes

data.value: In February 2012, the Board approved a program to repurchase up to five million shares (the '2012 Program'), subsequently extended through February 20, 2021. During 2020, 1,140,819 shares were repurchased at an aggregate cost of $87.5 million and retired.

On August 6, 2020, the Board approved a program to repurchase up to ten million shares (the '2020 Program') through August 6, 2025. Under this program, during the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021, and 2020, the Company repurchased 736,536 shares at $71.3 million, 445,711 shares at $47.7 million, and 2,490,599 shares at $177.8 million respectively, with a cumulative total of 3,672,846 shares repurchased at $296.9 million as of December 31, 2022.
As of December 31, 2022, 6,327,154 shares of the Company’s common stock remained available for repurchase under the program.

data.key: Additional Repurchase Related to Stock Plans
data.value: During the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021, and 2020, the Company purchased and retired shares from plan participants (72,886 shares at approximately $7.0 million in 2022, 251,946 shares at $30.6 million in 2021, and 111,451 shares at $10.4 million in 2020) to cover exercise prices or tax withholding obligations.
In connection with the Separation, the Company called its 3.25% Convertible Notes for redemption and issued 3,050,850 shares of common stock in 2021 as part of that redemption.

elements.title: Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations

data.value: The section contains forward-looking statements that involve risks, uncertainties, and assumptions, with a caution that actual results may differ materially.
Readers are advised to review the risk factors discussed in Part I, Item 1A and other SEC filings.

On October 7, 2021, the Company completed the separation of its cloud fax business into an independent publicly traded company, Consensus Cloud Solutions, Inc., which involved distributing 80.1% of Consensus shares to J2 Global stockholders while retaining a 19.9% interest.

The Company entered into a Fifth Amendment on June 10, 2022 and a Sixth Amendment on September 15, 2022 to its Credit Agreement with MUFG Union Bank, N.A., facilitating two debt-for-equity exchanges related to the Investment in Consensus.

Under the Fifth Amendment, approximately $90.0 million was borrowed and settled by a non-cash exchange of 2.3 million shares; under the Sixth Amendment, $22.3 million was borrowed and settled via a non-cash exchange of 0.5 million shares.
The Investment in Consensus is treated as equity securities with fair value changes reported in continuing operations. As of December 31, 2022, the Company held approximately 1.1 million shares.

elements.title: Credit Agreement Financing, Amendments, and Debt Restructuring Details

data.value: Amounts borrowed under the Credit Agreement bear interest at a base rate (the greater of the Federal Funds Effective Rate + 0.5%, the U.S. Dollar Reference Rate, or LIBOR + 1.00%) or at a rate based on LIBOR adjusted by LIBOR Reserve Requirements, plus an applicable margin ranging from 0.50%-1.25% for base rate loans and 1.50%-2.25% for LIBOR loans, depending on the Company's total leverage ratio.
April 7, 2026

On June 2, 2021, June 21, 2021, August 20, 2021, and September 16, 2021, the Company executed four Amendments which included issuance of a senior secured term loan (Bridge Loan Facility of $485.0 million), spin-off of the Company’s cloud fax business, and other changes.

The Bridge Loan Facility, fully drawn in Q3 2021 at $485.0 million, had tiered interest rates based on time intervals and matured 364 days after funding with potential automatic extensions if SEC approval for the spin-off was pending.

On October 7, 2021, in exchange for an equity interest in Consensus, the Company had $500.0 million of senior notes due 2028 issued, which were exchanged with lenders leading to extinguishment of outstanding indebtedness under the Bridge Loan Facility.
Carrying value at December 31, 2022 was $58.4 million, approximately 1.7% of consolidated total assets. A $2.00 share price change results in an approximate $2.2 million unrealized gain or loss.

elements.title: Risk Factors

data.value: Before deciding to invest in Ziff Davis or to maintain or increase your investment, you should carefully consider the risks described below.
Acquisitions and investments in our business play a significant role in our growth.
Acquisitions may disrupt our operations and harm our operating results.
The majority of our revenue within the Digital Media business is derived from short-term advertising arrangements.
We face risks associated with system failures, security breaches, and other technological issues.
We face risks associated with changes in our tax rates or tax treatment of companies.
We face risks associated with weakened global and U.S. economic conditions.
The markets in which we operate are highly competitive.
We face potential liability for various types of legal claims.
We may be subject to risks from international operations.
We may be found to infringe the intellectual property rights of others.
Our business is dependent on the supply of services from other companies.
Our business is dependent on our retention of our executive officers.
Our level of indebtedness could adversely affect our financial flexibility.
We are exposed to risk if we cannot maintain our internal controls.

elements.title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations

data.value: We face risks associated with our 1.75% Convertible Notes and 4.625% Senior Notes, including possible changes in interest deductions, triggering of the conditional conversion feature, lack of funds to settle conversions, and restrictions on future debt.
Divestitures or other dispositions could negatively impact our business, and contingent liabilities from sold businesses could adversely affect our financial statements.
Potential indemnification liabilities to Consensus pursuant to the separation agreement could materially affect our businesses and financial condition.
ESG matters and related reporting obligations expose us to risks that could adversely affect our reputation and performance.
We are subject to laws and regulations worldwide, which could increase our costs and adversely affect our business.
We may be exposed to government actions regarding data privacy and security, such as GDPR and CCPA, imposing significant compliance costs.
Developments in the healthcare industry and regulations could adversely affect our business.
Our business could suffer if broadband internet access services block or degrade our services.
Our business faces risks associated with advertisement blocking technologies and advertising click fraud.
Rapid technological changes in our industries may challenge our ability to keep up.
Conversions of Convertible Notes would dilute existing stockholders' ownership.
Our subsidiaries may face restrictions on their ability to pay dividends, impacting our financial strategies.
Our stock price may be volatile or decline due to various industry and regulatory changes.
Acquisitions and investments are crucial for our growth; failing to execute may harm our financial condition.
Disruptions from acquisitions may harm our operating results.

elements.title: Cybersecurity Risks and Operational Vulnerabilities

data.value: Increased risk of system failure, security breaches, and unauthorized access to customer data.
Potential harm to operating results and financial condition due to increased costs or diminished revenue.
Harm to reputation due to data breaches or cyber-attacks.
Reliance on third-party vendors for security and services increases vulnerability.
Cybersecurity threats are continually evolving, creating ongoing challenges.
Insurance coverage for cybersecurity incidents may not fully cover all potential losses.

elements.title: Economic Conditions and Competitive Pressure

data.value: Weakened global and U.S. economy conditions, volatility in the economy, and political instability may adversely affect us and certain of our customers.
The COVID-19 pandemic disrupted and may continue to disrupt economic activity, affecting commercial confidence and spending.
The impact of economic sanctions and export controls in connection with geopolitical conflicts is uncertain.
Climate change may have long-term adverse impacts on business locations and could disrupt critical operations.
Changes in regulatory requirements regarding climate change may impact business and financial conditions.
The markets are highly competitive, with significant competition from larger companies with greater resources.

elements.title: Competitive Landscape and Brand Management Risks

data.key: Analysis of Competitors and Market Risks
data.value: Many competitors possess significant resources and market advantages that could lead to slower growth for our products.
Effective brand management is crucial; failure to strengthen brands could adversely impact business.
If trademark protection is inadequate, brand value may diminish, impacting competitiveness and subscriber attraction.
Potential tax liabilities if the separation of Consensus does not qualify for tax-free status under the IRS.

elements.title: Transitional Service Agreement (TSA) Provisions and Operational Transition

data.value: Confidential and accurate inventory of all MFL assets deployed in YOW.
Ziff Davis to provide unracking services to Consensus, after which Consensus's vendor will take custody of MFL assets.
Consensus is prohibited from modifying or handling any equipment in production cabinets owned by Ziff Davis.
Ziff Davis to provide continued shared network device and internet access (in Dublin and Ottawa) while new circuits are installed; both parties will use existing network until separation is complete.

Provisions include maintaining access to DNS records (ns1-5 A records), phone number accounts with various vendors (Lumen, Inexio, Axialys, ViaDialog, VodaFone, Equinix), and SIP endpoint access; responsibilities for charges and out-of-pocket costs incurred solely due to the requested service.
Key dates include March 31, 2023 (Dublin), November 30, 2022 (Ottawa), December 31, 2022, October 31, 2022, among others noted per service item.
Mutual support for using service providers (Lumen, Vodafone, Inexio, Colt) while confirming distinct circuits and separate portal usage between Consensus and Ziff Davis.
Ziff Davis to support and facilitate the decommissioning and moving of Consensus hardware not needed at YOW and Dublin; costs to be borne by Consensus.
Ziff Davis to administer payroll for transitionary employees until Consensus finalizes moving off Ziff Davis, with reimbursement terms specified.
Agreement concludes at the End of Term as specified.
